items.title: S&P 500 tries to avoid worst streak since 2022; Nasdaq Composite, Dow Jones near flatline
items.description: A fifth consecutive weekly decline would mark the index’s worst losing streak since 2022, underscoring the persistent unease gripping Wall Street

items.title: Bulk Deals: Nippon India picks 28 lakh shares of TBO Tek, Norges Pension Fund sells 7 lakh Nazara Tech shares
items.description: In today's session, the market’s fiery run continued, with the Nifty locking in its best weekly performance in four years, soaring 4.27 percent—a feat last seen in February 2021, when it had surged 9.46 percent.

items.title: Wall Street opens lower as trade jitters and tech weakness weigh on markets
items.description: Stocks saw a brief respite midweek after the Federal Reserve maintained its outlook for two rate cuts in 2025, but broader concerns kept risk appetite in check.

items.title: FII net buy shares worth Rs 7,470 crore, DIIs net sellers of Rs 3,202 crore
items.description: For the year so far, FIIs have been net sellers of shares worth Rs 1.57 lakh crore, while DIIs have net bought Rs 1.81 lakh crore worth of shares.

items.title: More than 250 smallcaps post double digit return as index post biggest gain since June 2020
items.description: During the week, the BSE Large-cap index added 4.6 percent, while BSE Mid-cap index rising 7 percent, posting biggest weekly gain Since February 2021 and BSE Small-cap index gaining nearly 8 percent, recording biggest gain since June 2020.

items.title: Wall Street ends higher, dollar rises as Trump signals tariff respite
items.description: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 31.88 points, or 0.08%, to 41,985.20, the S&P 500 rose 4.55 points, or 0.08%, to 5,667.44 and the Nasdaq Composite rose 92.43 points, or 0.52%, to 17,784.05.

items.title: Market posts best weekly gain in 4 years; rupee appreciates
items.description: Indian rupee has registered a best week in over two years led by falling dollar index. During the week, the Indian rupee ended higher by 103 paise at 85.97 per dollar on March 21 against the March 13 closing of 87.
